text:
The Bombay High Court had issued a ‘criminal contempt of court’ notice to Arundhati Roy on December 23.

Justice Arun Choudhary had issued a ‘criminal contempt of court’ notice to Ms. Roy on December 23 last on an intervention petition filed by advocate S.P. Bhandarkar for making “scandalous and scurrilous allegations” against the judiciary in an article published in Outlook magazine in May 2015. He asked her to be present in court.

In a surprise move, Justice V.M. Deshpande recused himself from the matter on Monday.

The case was then taken up in the court of Justices Gavai and Deshmukh, who disagreed with the argument of K.H. Deshpande, counsel for Ms. Roy, that a matter of criminal contempt could be heard only by the Chief Justice and not by any other judge.

“Agreeing with your contention would be negation of Article 215 of the Constitution,” Justice Gavai said.

The Division Bench also refused to hear another intervention proposed by advocate Bhandarkar against Supreme Court lawyer Prashant Bhushan and asked him to file the petition after the Supreme Court decided on Ms. Roy’s application.

Last week, the Supreme Court sought a response from the High Court and the Maharashtra government after Ms. Roy argued that criminal contempt proceedings amounted to choking dissent and produced an “intense chilling effect” on the fundamental right of free expression.
title: No need for Arundhati Roy to appear, says court
